Posts.Content: At the moment they use a fairly crude algorithm that is a simple linear function that doesn't involve any separate categories. It was developed with statistical methods that were common ten years ago. I suspect that refinements ( perhaps a gen-2 Decipher) will employ more recent multivariate methods that are now being used in genomic research. Considering the first commentary article you cited, GenomeDx might, for instance add a "channel" that considers the co-occurrence of elevations in SPOP, PTEN and TP53 expression (none of which are included in hte current algorithm.) Since my profile has elevations of both SPOP and TP53, I might get reclassified. Only my PTEN is low of those three. So I do understand low-risk by Decipher might still include subcategories with high risk "triples" or "quads". Whether those subcategories would be susceptible to any one of the hormonal or anti-neoplastic agents would then be a separate issue for study.
Posts.Title: This Crazy Disease

Posts.Content: @DijnTonic: This is the inverse of the situation that we are both in. They found a genetic pattern associated with what is considered a low-risk Gleason pattern, but a demonstrated metastatic behavior. We both have a high-risk patterns but low-risk Decipher scores. It's my sincere hope and tentative belief that the genetics are what best characterize malignant potential. I suspect that qualitative light microscopic grading will be supplanted by a more quantitative "molecular" approach in the coming decades. PS: The last date in your sig probably needs to be revised.
Posts.Title: This Crazy Disease

Posts.Content: My reading of the copy that I got has the summary of changes on page 4. They primarily involve details about indications for enzalutamide (now for both MO and MI CRPC) and abiraterone (additional indications for co-administration with corticosteroids in various settings of CRPC).
Posts.Title: New NCCN Guidelines for Clinical Prostate Guidelines for Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: The reason for thinking that proton beam therapy _should_ be more effective is that protons are rather "heavy" compared to x-rays. They are also physically in a different category of particle. They are therefore stopped at more predictable distances after travelling through tissue. This lets the radiotherapists and radiation physicists plan a treatment protocol that they feel is better because they know more precisely where the protons will be stopping, whereas xrays (gamma rays) deliver their energy to the tissues along their entire track. (I hope this is sufficiently clear but I admit that I sometime speak "over people's heads". My undergrad training was in physics and my medical training wasn't particularly helpful in bringing my vocabulary down to "street level".) All that said, the most recent PubMed abstracts that I have read indicate no superiority of Proton Beam therapy over external beam gamma radiation or combined brachytherapy with external beam radiation, either in mortality or side-effect probability. Since it was supposed to be superior at least with regard to side-effects, the consensus committees are not considering it "standard". I'm not sure whether this link will be preserved since I am a new user, but if it gets automagically deleted then you could also search PubMed with a strategy of "proton beam prostate neoplasms review": https://www.cancer.net/specific-type...d-side-effects
Posts.Title: Proton Therapy Advice?

Posts.Title: Proton Therapy Advice?

Posts.Content: There are articles appearing that show that Decipher has comparable predictive power when used with needle biopsy results obtained before surgery in the case of men eventually choosing prostatectomy: EUROPEAN UROLOGY 73 (201 168–175 "Validation of a Genomic Risk Classifier to Predict Prostate Cancer-specific Mortality in Men with Adverse Pathologic Features", first author R. Jeffrey Karnes https://www.europeanurology.com/arti...17)30264-6/pdf And this article is probably describes a group of men who are included in that article above, but with a focus on high-risk radiotherapy treated patients. Prostate Cancer and Prostatic Diseases (2017) 20, 186–192 OPEN ACCESS "Utilization of biopsy-based genomic classifier to predict distant metastasis after definitive radiation and short-course ADT for intermediate and high-risk prostate cancer", first author PL Nguyen https://www.nature.com/articles/pcan201658 One advantage to the Decipher methodology is that the estimates of risk are derived from metastatic outcomes rather than BCR outcomes. I used my result of 0.22 on the most recent version of the test to support my decsion to stop ADT after 6 months despite my GS that put me in a high-risk category. The initial FDA approved indications for the test were limited to surgically-treated cases, so doctors giving "generally-accepted" or "protocol-endorsed" advice might not be telling you about this option. My physicians were following the NCCN protocols, which are solidly based on science from 5-10 years ago. Genomic methods get a passing nod in those protocol documents, but the results from randomized trials are not yet available, so there's no specific strategy for its use yet endorsed. Recently GenomeDx began offering Decipher-Biopsy as a service done in their lab. Cost is around 3,000 USD.
Posts.Signature: Age 69. Retired generalist physician. (undergrad in physics.) Also have (had?) GS 9 prostate cancer, treated with curative intent using 6 mo ADT, HDR-brachy (38 Gy avg) and IMRT (39 Gy). Decided to stop ADT (Sept 2017) after getting biopsy-Decipher results (3 versions from percentile page): .. decipher_1 0.11 .. decipherv2_1 0.13 .. decipherv2_2 0.22 Last 2 PSA's 3 months apart: both 1.0 ng/ml.

Posts.Title: The Decipher Test for Predicting Metastasis in Post-RP Patients with Persistent PSA

Posts.Content: You might try your local hospital's medical library. The Journal of Urology is pretty standard so even the least comprehensive hospital library should have it. I'm a Kaiser member and a retired physician and that organization does NOT allow its members to use their library, but I'm pretty sure that all of the community hospitals I have worked for in the past would have allowed patients to get articles.
Posts.Title: How to read original source documents without paying $40/download ??

Posts.Content: Dear ozarks573; We're all hoping you will have a tolerable course of treatment and a favorable long-term result. About a year and a half ago I picked a similar course of therapy as did you. I did so after spending quite a bit of time researching the outcomes on PubMed. I was offered robotic surgery, open surgery, EBRT or high-dose brachytherapy with EBRT boost. (I picked the last one but I don't think there's clear evidence that it's better, although it does involve fewer visits.) What I could find as far as randomized comparisons led me to believe the radiation modalities were equivalent to the surgical modalities in terms of mortality or recurrence probabilities and I preferred the side-effects profiles of the radiation choice. To the moderators that removed my earlier replies: can you tell me where they ended up? I cannot find them.
Posts.Title: Started Treatment Today ADT + EBRT

Posts.Title: Started Treatment Today ADT + EBRT

Posts.Content: I found the replies to this question somewhat interesting because of the implicit preference for surgery by the two respondents so far. I'm a retired physician, 1 year out from completing a course of ADT followed by HDR brachytherapy with EBRT boost for high-risk, multifocal GS 9=4+5. I made this decision (despite my urologists suggestion of surgery) because of the clear superiority of RT over RP in preservation of erectile function with equivalent longterm recurrence free survival. RT is also superior to RT in the significantly lower probability of either urinary incontinence or urethral stricture. There is a higher probability of radiation-induced dysuria with RT and I do have some, but my goals were to balance survival and sexual function. The criminally small number of good head-to-head comparisons (stratified by risk subsets) show survival to be equivalent and better preservation of sexual function with RT. At nine months after stopping ADT my PSA was down to 1.0 with a downward trend from the 6 month value of 1.2, so I'm seeing this as "on-track" with the reported trajectory of favorable outcomes after RT. (I can probably find the medical article if anyone else is interested.) My medical training included a fellowship in epidemiology and 20 years in life insurance assessment of mortality risk. In assessing life insurance risk, I alway gave preference to surgically treated cases because of the superior information from the biopsy specimen and the quick decline of PSA to <0.1, but when the decision became personal, I went for RT "on the personal merits". I later chose to pay for one of the biopsy-derived genetic prognostic batteries (GenomeDx's "genomic classifier") to decide whether to continue ADT (which I found intensely unpleasant) and after it came back very low risk (22nd percentile) I decided to stop the ADT (against my radiotherapists' advice).
